WASHINGTON, June 18--The Senate agreed today to vote at 2 P.M. tomorrow on whether the present Reciprocal Trade Agreements law shall be expanded, as asked by the Administration and approved by the House.

Spokesmen of France in this country, addressing the French American Club dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night, urged the Truman Administration to consider Gen. Charles de Gaulle in a new light.

PARIS, June 18--Fifty thousand troops marched through Paris today and Gen. Charles de Gaulle took their salute, with the Sultan of Morocco at his side, thus marking by a great military display the fifth anniversary of the General's famous broadcast from London which initiated the Resistance Movement.

Despite the difficulties of wartime transportation, the annual exodus of youngsters to summer camps in New York State, New England and near-by States will not be seriously curtailed although posing a problem for camp directors not faced in former years, a survey disclosed yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 18--The application of American Light and Power Company for permission to acquire for $5,000 the initially issued fifty shares of $100 par value capital stock of a proposed pipeline company was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 18-- Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, announced tonight that, as a result of a gift from Herbert Lowell Dillon, New York banker and a member of the Class of '07, the construction of Princeton's new $1,100,000 gymnasium was assured.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP)-- Senator Tydings of Maryland accused Drew Pearson, columnist, from the Senate floor today, of attempted "blackmail," and of having had affiliations with "one of the great gambling rackets in America."

LONDON, June 18--The Stock markets opened the week on a quiet note. Although business was restricted by the forthcoming election, the general tone was steady.

Parking lots at New York's race tracks, closed since the beginning of the war, will be thrown open to automobilists tomorrow, Wednesday, according to an announcement by officials of the five tracks yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 18--Quotas for the production of 227,000 domestic mechancical refrigerators have been assigned to nine manufacturers under the 265,000-unit program for July, August and September, the War Production Board reported today. The remaining 38,000 probably will be authorized this week, it was said.

IN the autumn of 1943 a London news agent who had spent the greater part of his life selling newspapers, stationery and odds and ends received a mysterious call from an elderly gentleman who asked him if he believed in fairies. Now, because of the singular circumstances of his birth, Sergius Wilfred Allenby could not give the conventional disclaimer and send his visitor about his business. He had to admit that he did.

PARIS, June 18--Gen. Charles de Gaulle, according to semi-official French quarters, was tonight preparing a public reply to the British and American rejection of his proposal for a five-power conference on Syria and will deliver it before the Consultative Assembly tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 18--After two or more false starts in recent weeks, the Supreme Court was finally able to race through its cases today and end its work until October. It was a hectic day with the wide divergence in views which has marked the entire term.

Low-price rail shares again dominated trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange in one of the strongest carrier markets in years. Leading industrial shares, which had been heavy for days, continued to lag despite the in creased business. The turnover was 1,930,000 shares.

The national banks of this country served the credit needs of more persons at less cost during 1944 than in 1943, and ended the year with a stronger capital structure and a slight increase in earned profits, according to the annual report of the national bank division, American Bankers Association.

Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, announced yesterday his decision not to seek the Republican nomination for Mayor in the primary election despite his dissatisfaction with the ticket named by the Republican county leaders.

Charles Triller, New York business man, has been elected chairman of the board of directors of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Triller replaces Marshall Field, who retained his post as president of the society.

TRENTON, N.J., June 18--Mr. and Mrs. Louis S. Kaplan of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Charmian, to Maj. Seelig Freund, Medical Corps, AUS, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Freund of New York.

LONDON, June 18--The taunting, sarcastic voice that had infuriated or amused millions of Britons was subdued and respectful today as William Joyce, known and despised as Lord Haw Haw of the German radio, faced London's chief metropolitan magistrate. The British expatriate was charged with high treason under a statute framed 600 years ago.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 18-- The Committee on Membership, Secretariat and Amendment, which had the largest agenda of important unfinished business of any of the twelve technical committees of the conference on Friday, finished its work in a burst of speed at a session which went on almost all day Sunday and ended at 12:50 this morning.

Taxicabs in this city now carry nearly twice as many passengers as in 1941, although the available equipment has decreased, it was discovered yesterday. Before Pearl Harbor 11,678 taxicabs carried 360,000 persons daily. Latest reports from the United Taxi Council show that 9,137 units now have 700,000 customers each day.

If Reuben B. Resnik of the American Joint Distribution Committee is right in his estimate the Nazis exterminated at least 5,000,000 European Jews. On the Continent outside of Russia about 1,000,000 survive. The war against the Jews of Germany was but a minor episode in this ghastly slaughter, for in 1939 there were only about 240,000 German Jews.

A benefit exhibition arranged to aid the Save the Children Federation, Inc., will open this afternoon at the American British Art Center, 44 West Fifty-sixth Street. It is made up of Austrian paintings of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 21 (AP)-- Two favorites and a pair of comparative unknowns today crashed into the semi-final round of the sixteenth annual women's western open golf tournament over the sundrenched Highland Golf and Country Club course.

Summer came into being officially yesterday under sunny skies, arriving inconspicuously at 2:52 P.M., bringing with it a balmy temperature of 76 degrees and in its wake last evening a heavy rain and hailstorm.

Thomas G. Bellantoni, of 100 Hollywood Avenue, Albany, N.Y., known for many years in political circles on the lower East Side and in Albany as Tommy Dyke, died on Thursday in Albany, according to word received here yesterday. His age was 49.

BOSTON, June 21--The Navy transport Admiral Mayo debarked 5,807 more European war veterans today, including a 28-year-old New York technical sergeant who has the amazing total of 276 points, the highest recorded in the European war theatre.

WASHINGTON, June 21--Republican support for a reorganization of the price control structure along the lines suggested by former President Hoover developed today as the House ended two days of general debate on the Administration bill to extend the present price control act without change.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP)-- American business men are planning to spend a record-breaking $4,500,000,000 for plants, equipment and alterations during the fiscal year starting July 1.

LONDON, June 21--A report that Premier Stalin assured Harry Hopkins, during the latter's recent visit to Moscow, that a general amnesty would follow any convictions of the Poles who were seized in Moscow is circulating today among Poles here not connected with the exiled Government.
BRUSSELS, June 21--Keen interest was manifested today in the possibility that King Leopold might have selected Paul van Zeeland, pie-war Premier, to succeed Premier Achille van Acker.

CHUNGKING, China, June 21 (U.P.)--Chinese forces, driving for Hangchow Bay, have forced the Wu River and advanced thirty-one miles beyond Wenchow against only fitful resistance from the rapidly withdrawing Japanese, it was announced tonight.

BOMBAY, India, June 21 (U.P.)-- The Working Committee of the All-India Congress party, nationalist organization aiming at independence, has decided to take part Monday in the Simla conference on British proposals to give India a greater degree of self-government, it was reported tonight.

The deep concern of the United States in freedom of the press as an instrument for the promotion of international understanding and friendship was emphasized by President Truman and Secretary of State Edward R. Stettinius Jr. in letters made public yesterday.

Standley, former United States Ambassador to the U.S.S.R.

DETROIT, June 21 (AP)--With Frank (Stubby) Overmire spacing seven hits and driving in two runs, the league-leading Tigers cuffed the Indians, 5 to 1, today, sweeping a three-game series.

The board of directors of Bowman-Biltmore Hotels Corporation has approved a plan of reorganization under which 66,024 shares of 7 per cent cumulative first preferred stock will be reclassified into 396,144 shares of new $1 par common stock, on the basis of six common for each first preferred share, it was declared yesterday by Martin Sweeny, president.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (U.P.)-- Award of Distinguished Service Medals to nine officers and seamen of the merchant marine who gave or risked their lives to save comrades was announced tonight by the Maritime Commission.

Bullitt, president of the Orchestra Association, announced today in presenting the annual report to the board of directors.

Governors of the New York Stock Exchange voted yesterday to close the Exchange on Saturdays during July and August and on Sept. 1, the Saturday preceding Labor Day. Other securities and some commodities exchanges and over-the-counter dealers indicated they would follow suit.

In an unprecedented move George H. Chatfield, chairman of the Board of Education's finance committee, called upon his fellow board members yesterday to join him in seeking an additional $5,951,720 from the city to supplement the $44,343,037 already appropriated.

WASHINGTON, June 21--Higher prices for cotton textiles as a result of increased labor costs were forecast by the Office of Price Administration today as it advised manufacturers they would be allowed to adjust prices with their customers in the event price ceilings are raised at a later date.

After holding steady early in the session yesterday, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier in the late trading, and final prices closed barely steady 5 to 13 points net lower than Wednesday.

Buch, director of the New Jersey Rehabilitation Commission and chairman of the State Crippled Children's Commission, died today in his home here of a coronary thrombosis. His age was 63. He had served as Grand Exalted Ruler of the Elks in the United States in 1940 and 1941.

In 1900 Hawaii began a battle With a bug. The sugar cane leafhopper, a tiny insect believed to be a native of Australia, made its appearance on Oahu. The whole sugar industry was faced with ruin.

GUAM, Sunday, June 24 (AP)-- American air attacks Friday by light planes on Kyushu, southernmost Japanese main island--in addition to the B-29 operations early that day--were reported briefly today by Fleet Admiral Chester W. Nimitz.

THE newly formed company known as Leonide Mas sine's "Ballet Russe Highlights" will make its bow to New York in two performances at the Lewisohn Stadium on next Saturday and Sunday evenings. The programs will consist exclusively of divertissements, some of ...
WASHINGTON, June 23--The Government's quiet and earnest fight against inflation was encountering this week a new and bewildering set of obstacles.
BOSTON, June 23 (AP)--The Washington Senators brought in the tying and winning runs without a base hit today to beat the Boston Red Sox, 6 to 5.

SOME guys want to win medals--and some guys want to win wars," said one of Captain Genovese's fellow-pilots who flew unarmed transports with him over the Hump from India to China. Emperor Hirohito addressed a personal message to the Japanese people yesterday, telling them that "the present crisis is unprecedented in scope in our national history" and "graciously" expressing his satisfaction at the "valor and courage" of his people, it was reported by Domei, Japanese news agency.

A POST-WAR, program of farreaching ramifications has been announced by the Greyhound Lines following a four-day meeting in Chicago, where definite plans for making highway buses more attractive to travelers were presented by a group of experts.

WASHINGTON, June 23--America's overburdened railroads, far from enjoying a post V-E Day respite are already up to their smokestacks in a redeployment job that threatens to bring on the country's worst transportation jam before the year is out.

QUEBEC, June 23--The International Labor Organization today heard warnings by several speakers that promises were not enough and that hard work and strict attention to realities would be necessary if the aim of jobs for everybody was to be attained.

MANILA, Sunday, June 24--Australian Ninth Division troops on Borneo have seized the great Seria oil fields without opposition after a spectacular sixty-mile march southwest down the island's north coast, General MacArthur's headquarters announced today.
OKINAWA, June 20 (Delayed) (AP)--Gen. H.H. Arnold, five-star chief of the United States Army Air Forces, predicted today that Japan would have little industry left by fall.

AS summer comes to stay, a small garden has a very special charm in its ease of upkeep and simplicity. The dooryard garden is almost of necessity limited and can easily be the most delightful of all such plantings.
The handicap list issued by the Metropolitan Golf Association, through Chairman Shepard Barnes of Baltusrol, shows an increase since renewal of activities last year.

SO many hastily conceived and poorly written books for chil dren on Latin America have appeared that a writer on this subject faces a handicap. Let no one, however, dismiss Miss Shippen's volume as merely "another book on Latin America."

Senator James E. Murray of Montana called last night for stern measures against German militarism, asserting that the Germans already have embarked on a "preliminary program" of indoctrinating the United States with the myth of German innocence.

With regular communication between the New York offices of the Holland-American Line, at 29 Broadway, and its office in Rotterdam soon to be resumed after five years of wartime interruption, Peter van den Toorn, the line's United States managing director, has disclosed the fate of the company's six ships that were docked in Rotterdam at the time the Germans invaded.

And now it's summer, officially. The solstice has come and the sun has begun its long glide southward--or so it seems as our earth swings on its orbital axis. The year's longest day is just behind us, and ahead lies the accumulated heat of July, the bake-oven blast that is August.
OLYMPIA, Wash., June 23 (AP)-- President Truman worked today on plans for his forthComing "Big Three" meeting, devoting much of his time to a review of last-minute reports from all over the world.

Announcement by the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration that five European nations will receive 50,000 heifers, cows and mares in the next year and a half points to one of the major problems in re-establishing normal farm operations ...
LONDON, June 23--Many British voters are becoming disgusted with the irrelevancies of the general election campaign, now in its final fortnight.

BOSTON, June 23--A bitter fight looms in Massachusetts over proposed legislation against discrimination in employment. The bill may well become an important political issue in the 1946 election campaign and the controversy may have some bearing on similar proposals in other States.

BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., June 23--Miss Margaret Rutherfurd White, daughter of John Campbell White, who until recently was United States Ambassador to Peru, and Mrs. White of New York, was married in St. Bernard's Episcopal Church here this afternoon to Second Lieut. William Tapley Bennett Jr., AUS, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bennett of Pine Mountain Valley and Savannah, Ga. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert Bosher.

IF the argument advanced by Mr. Reves is sound, the San Francisco Conference has been a waste of time and any league that comes out of it will be "the pitiful miscarriage of the second World War." These things are ...

THIS is a most readable book that will appeal to those whose interest has been stirred by the fragmentary accounts in the war news of the rocket as a weapon and as a means of propulsion. The author has been an officer in the American Rocket.

TAMIMENT, Pa., June 23-- Henry Hazlitt, of the editorial Staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES, told the Tamiment Conference to day that "under genuinely free enterprise unhampered by Government policies or intervention or by coercive monopolies either of capital or of labor, there can be no such thing as prolonged mass unemployment."

CAMP SHANKS, N.Y., June 23--Combat units of the Ninetyseventh Infantry Division began arriving here today from Europe after a thiry-mile sail up the Hudson in bright sunlight that contrasted sharply with the chill winter night five months ago when they hurriedly steamed out of New York harbor.
IN 1942 the Museum of Modern Art published a catalogue of its permanent collection, which then contained just short of 700 items.

A couple of Yankee players who have been held in something less than high esteem provided the victory punch yesterday as the Clan McCarthy downed the hapless Athletics in a ninth-inning bit of excitement to an ordinary game and registered their third victory in a row before 11,500 fans. The count was 7 to 6.

CHUNGKING, China, June 23 (AP)--Ranging over a vast 1,350mile aerial front in China, American bombers and fighters yesterday blasted Japanese strongholds from Indo-China to Peiping, while Chinese forces routed 2,000 enemy troops in southwestern Honan Province, United States and Chinese communiques said today.

Two million persons, reacting in part to temperatures that were nine degrees above normal and in part to the metropolitan urge for week-end excursions, celebrated the first Sunday of summer at beaches and other resorts near the city yesterday, according to official estimates.

Reversing the result of their meeting in the semi-finals of the national championship last year, Francisco (Pancho) Segura of Ecuador defeated William Talbert of Wilmington, Del., yesterday as the Red Cross victory exhibitions came to a close in the Forest Hills Stadium.

EMPORIUM, Pa., June 24.-- B.G. Erskine, chairman of the board and former president of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., one of the pioneers in the radiotube industry, died at his home here yesterday. He was born in Buffalo sixty-two years ago.

PARIS, June 24--American soldiers in Europe, absorbed in every pursuit from pondering the Articles of War to skiing, find that they have less time on their hands now than they had when the war was going on.

LONDON, June 24--The reestablishment of the "most-favored nation" principle contained in numerous commercial treaties Czechoslovakia had with other nations but which lapsed as a result of the German invasion is a prime concern of the Czech Foreign Ministry, according to information from Prague to business men here.
GUAM, Monday, June 25--The Japanese have suffered nearly 110,000 casualties in the Okinawa campaign.

Any hopes held by manufacturers of civilian apparel that Army cutbacks of textiles in the third quarter would soon follow the pattern laid down by the Navy must be termed "wishful thinking," Worth Street textile men asserted yesterday.

HAMILTON, Mass., June 24 (U.P.) --Gen. George S. Patton Jr., Third Army commander, predicted today that the second World War would be the "last war if we are prepared against the possibility of future wars."

There have been many changes in the picture of childhood need in New York since the Children's Aid Society began its work ninety-three years ago. Services once rendered to unfortunate little folk have ceased to be required. Services then unforeseen have had to be undertaken.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 24-- The leading part in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's screen version of "The Green Years" has been assigned to Tom Drake, young contract actor, who played the boy next door in "Meet Me in St. Louis."

WILTON, N.H., June 24--Miss Beulah E. Emmet, daughter of Commodore Robert R.M. Emmet, USN, commanding officer of the Naval Training Station at Great Lakes, and Mrs. Emmet of New York, was married to Dr. Frederick Hiebel of New York, son of Mrs. Gustav Hiebel of Newtown.
PARIS, June 24--Gen. Charles de Gaulle has proposed to Washington several possible dates during July when he would like to visit President Truman.

LONDON, June 24--Definite limitations on the extent to which high Nazi war criminals will be permitted to becloud the issue of their guilt by summoning heads of other governments as witnesses can be expected to be imposed by the special war criminal tribunal, it was stated authoritatively here today.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., June 24-- On the large fleet of craft that set out last night in the Riverside Yacht Club's fifty-mile race out around Stratford Shoal and return there must have been thoughts of adding a burden to the talk about a gas shortage.

An investment of $216,000,000 was made by national advertisers for space in weekday and Sunday newspapers in 1944, it was announced by the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, in releasing today the sixth annual edition of its standard reference book, "Ex- ...

The executive committee of the City Fusion party has endorsed Edgar J. Nathan Jr., Borough President of Manhattan, for renommation and re-election, Gabriel A. Wechsler, general secretary of the party, announced yesterday.

SIMLA, India, June 24 (AP)-- Mohandas K. Gandhi decided tonight not to participate in the conference scheduled to open tomorrow at the call of Lord Wavell, British Viceroy, to devise a new government for India with broader political support.

A show-down over the threat of Daniel P. Woolley, regional head of the Office of Price Administration, to oust some of the attorneys of the regional and area enforcement staffs was in the making yesterday as Bronx County leaders of the American Labor party protested to Chester ...

BRUSSELS, June 24--King Leopold, addressing to his people today his first message since his capture by the Germans five years ago, underlined his refusal to consider abdication and his resolution ultimately to resume his place at the head of the nation.

There's something about wild raspberries that puts them in a special category. One finds them in the corners of stony-soiled upland fields, along brushhidden stone walls that circle meadows and divide pasture land from woods.

Encouraged by growing stockpiles of wool plus belief that Government requirements of jute will slacken as more manila becomes available, carpet and rug industry sources indicated last week that they were looking toward the fourth quarter with "hopeful expectancy" of more output of peacetime products.
Always on the lookout for suitable film material, Metro is arranging one of those pre-production deals with Gilbert Miller, now in London, for the Vina Delmar play.

Tokyo residents, who have already planted gardens and made fish ponds in the "burned ruins" of their city, have now for the first time planted rice paddies in the heart of the devastated Japanese capital, 'according to the Tokyo radio.

WASHINGTON, June 24--A special House subcommittee, criticizing some of the Navy's policies for disposing of its surplus facilities in the Mediterranean and European theatres, recommended today that the department consider transferring some of its big bases in those areas intact to the Pacific theatre to speed the war against Japan.

Twelve victorious generals came back from the European war yesterday afternoon. They arrived at La Guardia Field in four giant C-54 Army transports and a Flying Fortress, with twenty-four officers and twenty-five snecially selected enlisted men, after a flight from Paris.
CHICAGO, June 24--Industrial users of fats and oils look to the nation's farms and to slowly improving shipments of foreign oils to ease critical shortages of essential raw materials.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, June 24--Rough preliminary figures issued by the Netherlands Statistical Bureau estimate that the total war damage suffered by this nation amounts to more than 15,000,000,000 guilders in terms of 1938 price levels.

CHICAGO, June 24--More than 5,000 drivers of the American Federation of Labor and 10,000 soldier guards will be available tomorrow morning in the Government's effort to restore normal trucking to the Chicago area as the truck drivers' strike enters its tenth day, Office of Defense Transportation officials said tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP)-- Congressional ideas for maintenance of the country's economy should emphasize stability, rather than what to do when instability has been allowed to develop, Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, declared today.

Two four-story apartment houses on a plot 40 by 80 feet at 120-22 Lexington Avenue, northwest corner of Twenty-eighth Street, were sold by the Richard-Murray Corporation to a client of Williams Co. and Julius Matthews.

LONDON, June 24--The stock markets here are running true to the forecast that they would be very idle during the election campaign but they are much firmer than was generally expected. The City appears convinced that Prime Minister Winston Churchill will be returned with a sufficient working majority.
Nothing irritates a preacher more than to be told, "I enjoyed your sermon so much," the Rev. Robert E. Woods of the staff of St. Patrick's Cathedral declared at solemn mass there yesterday.
The Army's mammoth program of redeploying troops from Europe to the Pacific continued in full swing yesterday as seven overloaded transports brought here 8,810 veterans of the battle against Germany.

TAMIMENT, Pa., June 24-- Louis Waldman, New York labor lawyer and author, today told the final session of the Camp Tamiment Social and Economic Conference, of which he is permanent chairman, that "the great task of labor and liberal forces who take seriously the principles of democracy in the United States is to unite against the totalitarian forces."

SYDNEY, Australia, June 24 (U.P.) --Because they wore clothes, three American air-crash survivors and their paratrooper rescuers were all mistaken for women by the natives of "Hidden Valley," the New Guinea Shangri-La, where a transport plane cracked up five weeks ago, it was revealed tonight.

The management of the Aqueduct race track in Queens, where an eighteen-day meeting opens today, will be held responsible for failure to enforce the law against illegal gambling on the premises, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday after his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall.

PARIS, June 24--The relaxation or abolition of the non-fraternization rule for Allied troops in Germany and Austria is strongly urged by American and British commanders and military government officers in occupied zones.
Active sine June, 1943, the Emergency Committee to Save the Jewish People of Europe, Inc., has been dissolved because "its mandate has expired," it was announcerd yesterday.

With 30.5 per cent of the E bond goal still to be achieved in the State and 30.2 per cent in the city, the Seventh War Loan can be successful only if sales exceed $10,000,000 a day for the remaining period of the drive, War Finance Committee officials reported yesterday as the campaign enters its last week.

PROCESSED FOODS (canned or bottled fruits, vegetables, juices, tomatoes, catsup and chili sauce)--Blue stamps N2 through S2 valid through June 30. Stamps T2 through X2 valid through July 31. Stamps Y2, Z2, A1, B1 and C1 may be used through Aug. 31. Stamps Dl through Hl valid through Sent. 30.

After a record-breaking performance at Belmont, where an average daly crowd of 28,383 established a new world wagering mark by sending an average of $2,741,324 a day through the betting windows, racing has picked up its tack and moved to Aqueduct for the eighteen-day meeting of the Queens County Racing Association starting today.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 24-- Frank E. Simonson and Burt Braun, Garden City, C.C., were two under course figures to win, 4 and 3, from Dr. Ray Bowles and John Nicholson, Garden City C.C., in the final of the Cherry Valley Club member-guest, best-ball tournament today.

The start of summer finds most of us badly adjusted to the warm weather with the result that our hankering for iced tea and coffee, cold cuts, salads, ice cream and such is often greater than later in the season, when we have become inured to the heat.

MOSCOW, June 24--Adolf Hitler's personal swastika flag was dragged over Red Square today and hurled into a muddy gutter after Marshal Gregory K. Zhukoff, in a speech marking the victory parade, had said that the Red Army was the most powerful in the world, but that Russia must not become "conceited or complacent."

Most buyers managed to fill at least part of their needs in the wholesale merchandise markets here last week, although they may not have obtained precisely what they were seeking, according to reports prepared especially for THE ...

Mother Eleanor M. O'Byrne, college dean since 1934, today will succeed the late Mother Grace Cowardin Dammann as president of Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart, Convent Avenue and 133d Street, it was announced yesterday. Mother Florence Weston, assistant dean since September, will become dean.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 24 --Mrs. Imogene D. Stevens, member of a prominent New Canaan family, was arrested early this morning on a manslaughter charge in the fatal shooting of Albert Kovacs, 19-year-old sailor, who lived at 81 Ely Street, South Norwalk, and who was stationed at Portsmouth. N.H.
More than 87,000 of the country's workers were idle last night as standing labor disputes continued without settlement.

A program of physical therapy helped industrial plants maintain wartime production records by keeping workers in condition and returning the injured to their jobs with a minimum loss of time, the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis disclosed yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 24--Harvesting of the new winter wheat crop made rapid progress last week in parts of the Southwest. A big movement of new grain to terminal and subterminal markets is expected to get under way in about ten days if weather conditions remain favorable.

GUAM, Monday, June 25--Hundreds of American and British planes loosed more than 1,000 tons of bombs on sixteen enemy targets spread over a 5,000-mile front from Borneo to the Kuriles in a blazing week-end that carried forward the aerial offensive against Japan, reports here today showed.

An uncompleted building that has stood deserted for twenty years was revealed yesterday as the haunt of a murder gang. Two baby falcons that left their nest too soon, hurtling to the street twenty-three floors below, led to the scene of 200 murders--the victims all pigeons.

Even the Dodgers can't avoid the inevitable. Yesterday at Ebbets Field, after running their winning strack to eight games by beating the Braves, 9--6, in the opener they went down to defeat, 3--1, in the nightcap. Fortunately, other results allowed them to retain their three and one-half game first-place lead.

Wearing a short winter tunic that looked more like an enlisted man's blouse than a colonel's, the tank man who helped relieve the garrison at Bastogne in what many believe was the turning point in the final push to victory over the Nazi armies, told his story yesterday.

Choosing as his theme "The Transforming Cross," the Rev. Dr. Arthur J. Moore, resident bishop of the Atlanta, Ga., area of the Methodist Church, warned yesterday that it would be a gesture of insincerity and artificiality to deny or ignore the tragic implications the present world situation holds for the future of Christianity.

PARIS, June 23 (Delayed)-- Lady Spears, the wife of Maj. Gen. Sir Edward Spears, former British Minister to Syria and Lebanon, has been asked to leave France, it was learned today. Lady Spears is well known as a novelist under the name of Mary Borden.
The fight King Leopold of the Belgians is making for his throne is another instance of the quandary of royalty in the post-war world. The last war was fatal to emperors.
Daniel Cranford Smith, a former treasurer and trustee of the New School for Social Research, died in his penthouse at the school, 66 West Twelfth Street, on Saturday night. He was 79 years old.

The Department of Taxation and Finance of the State of New York will give a dinner in honor of David C. Krakaur, Estate Appraiser for the metropolitan district, and his assistant, Deputy Appraiser Charles W. Ferry, at the Hotel Commodore on Thursday at 6:30 P.M.

Two hunderd men and women volunteer workers at the Lenox Hill Hospital, Seventy-sixth Street and Park Avenue, last year contributed 61,825 hours of service, as nurse's aides, orderlies, dietetic and clerical assistants, trustees of the hospital disclosed yesterday.

The Rev. Dr. Arthur L. Carson, president of Silliman University in the Philippine Islands, called for greater moral, physical and spiritual aid for the people of the Philippines yesterday in his sermon at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street.

THREE years ago Dan Wickenden left his native Long Island and went to work for a newspaper in a small city in Michigan. He had already written two excellent and popular novels about family life, "The Running of the Deer" and "Walk Like a Mortal."
SAN FRANCISCO, June 24-- The Golden Gate city prepared today for one of the greatest occasions in its history, the welcoming of President Truman.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24-- After weeks of trials and tribulations our harried Giants finally brought themselves around to an even keel today, not to mention edging their way back into the National League's fourth place.

With the war half won we are already beginning to note how acutely needed are the positive, constructive forces "that we long to see loosed on the world," the Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker, rector of Calvary Episcopal Church, Twenty-first Street and Fourth Avenue, declared yesterday.
HONOLULU, June 24--Our aerial attacks on Japan will reach their peak in the fall, General Henry H. Arnold, commanding general of the Army Air Force said at Army headquarters here today.
The Tokyo radio claimed yesterday in a broadcast beamed to America areas that "enemy landing attempts" in the Balik Papan area of southeastern Borneo had been "completely checked."

CHUNGKING, China, June 24 (AP)--Chinese troops, pressing up China's eastern "invasion" coast in the wake of a Japanese withdrawal toward Shanghai, have reached Hwangyen, on Taichow Ba., 175 miles south of the great enemyheld seaport, the Chinese command said today.

PITTSBURGH, June 24--A combination of heat and outlaw steel strikes in some districts combined to keep the steel ingot rate at 90 per cent of rated capacity last week, unchanged from a revised rate of the week before.

A comprehensive program of rehabilitation and relief to be conducted this year by agencies affiliated with the reconstituted United Jewish Appeal was made public yesterday with the announcement of the election of Rabbi James G. Heller of Cincinnati, Rabbi Jonah B. Wise of New ...

After eighty-two days of conflict more violent than anything we have faced elsewhere in the Pacific theatre, Okinawa Island is ours. We are now able to estimate to some extent the results of the battle.

Cotton prices on the domestic market moved irregularly last week and net changes were comparatively small. At the close of trading on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 6 points to 6 points down from the close of the previous week.

No fan ever writes a letter with as much restraint, self-detachment, calmness and freedom from personalities as does an ingrained Dodger rooter. One such tender epistle recently was received from John J. Masterson of Brooklyn, who was aroused to crusading pitch by the most casual mention here of that paragon of diamond perfecion, Babe Herman.

ROSENHEIM, Germany, June 24 (AP)--A secret document in captured German archives indicated today that Mussolini and Hitler had tried vainly to get Generalissimo Francisco Franco to take Spain into the war in February, 1941, and that Hitler was angered at the failure.
The cost to the city of killing a steer and cutting it into meat for hospital patients was analyzed yesterday by Mayor La Guardia.

In 1944 debt service was met in full on $2,568,403,418 of publicly offered foreign dollar bonds, or 50.17 per cent of the total of $5,119,280,211 outstanding on Dec. 31, according to a bulletin entitled "Statistical Analysis of Publicly Offered Foreign Dollar Bonds," issued for release today by Dean John T. Madden, director of the ...

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 24-- In a light breeze that wafted in the western part of Long Island Sound the sixth championship regatta of the Yacht Racing Association was held today, the winners including Faulkner and O'Brien's international sloop Mischief, H.L. Jamison's Nepenthe in Class S and Walker and Kirk's Atlantic Phantom.

Howard S. Cullman, chairman, announced yesterday that the Port of New York Authority had offered to repay in Port Authority bonds $8,300,000 advanced by New York and New Jersey from 1926 to 1928 to aid in building the Outerbridge crossing and the Goethals and Bayonne Bridges, connecting Staten Island with New Jersey.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 24 (AP) --I have been asked by The Associated Press to give my general impression of the San Francisco Conference and the Charter of the United Nations which it has drafted.
In appraising the current food situation two aspects must be distinguished: production and distribution. Total production of food has declined moderately from last year's record total.

GUAM, June 24 (AP)--Iwo Island, which cost the lives of more than 4,000 American marines, has been a life-saving haven to more than twice that many B-29 crewmen within three month, Twenty-first Bomber Command Headquarters said today.

TEANECK, N.J., June 24--The finale of the annual all-breed show of the Kennel Club of Northern New Jersey today included four dogs that had best-in-show records, but when Mrs. George B. St. George completed her judging the better-known stars were led by a smooth foxterrier, Oppidan of Etona, bred and owned by John P. S. Harrison of New York.

The annual report of the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation and subsidiaries, issued to stockholders yesterday, disclosed a net profit for last year of $1,039,074 after all charges, including $100,000 provision for postwar adjustments and $3,303,570 for Federal taxes.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 24-- The marriage of Miss Patricia Rentsler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Guy Harold Rentsler of this city, to Lieut Hugh McCulloch Jr., Army Medical Corps, took place here this afternoon in Grace Episcopal Church.

How Benito Mussolini, vacillating, bragging, fearful of the consequences but yet unwilling to lose the opportunity for spoils, was drawn into the fateful military alliance with Nazi Germany is told in excerpts from the diaries of Count Galeazzo Ciano, Mussolini's son-in-law and Fascist Italy's Foreign Minister from 1936 to 1943.
CHICAGO, June 24--"Drumsticks" are here to stay, but the chicken of the future is going to be a white-meat bird.

The announcement from San Francisco that Poland will have a place reserved among the original signers of the new world charter brings to a happy ending a situation that might have been perilous as well as tragically ironical.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 24-- The French Government, through Joseph Paul-Boncour, chairman of the French delegation, appealed today to Secretary Stettinius as one of the four presidents of the United Nations Conference for "the appointment through a suitable procedure" of a commission to investigate and arbitrate the Levant controversy.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (U.P.)-- Senator Homer Capehart, Republican, of Indiana, back from a trip to Europe, declared tonight that the ban on fraternizing by United States service men with German women is unenforceable and should be revoked.

WASHINGTON, June 24-- Mounting costs of food and clothing were largely responsible for an increase of seven-tenths of 1 per cent in the cost of living for the month to May 15, Secretary Perkins reported today. The monthly rise from April 15 in the retail prices of living essentials was the greatest since May, 1943, she added.

Fifty thousand persons were stranded last evening at Orchard Beach, the Bronx, by the slowdown resulting from the refusal of Orchard Beach bus-line drivers employed by the Surface Transportation Company to work overtime.

MANILA, Monday, June 25-- Hundreds of veterans of the United States Eleventh Airborne Division, joined by gliders for the first time in the southwest Pacific, descended on the rice paddies near the north Luzon port of Aparri Saturday morning and swung south to join the final battle of the Cagayan Valley, where an estimated 20,000 Japanese are trapped.

LONDON, June 24--The new Polish Government established in the Moscow conferences last week will be composed of twenty-one members, sixteen being retained from the Warsaw Provisional Government and five being added from Poles abroad and inside Poland

Veterans of this war will demand a religion of action, not mere words, and a faith that is a living, functioning force, Army and Navy chaplains declared yesterday at the opening sessions of a four-day Rabbinical Assembly Conference at the Jewish Theological Seminary.

Immediate ratification by the United States Senate of the Charter for the General International Organization, written at San Francisco, is the prime objective in an eleven-point statement of policy announced yesterday by the board of directors of Americans United for World Organization.

One thousand representatives of Jewish organizations in this city launched a $2,000,000 emergency campaign for destitute European children at the sixth annual officers' luncheon of the Council of Organizations of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York at Webster Hall, 119 East Eleventh Street, yesterday.

DETROIT, June 24 (AP)--Slugging Sammy Byrd, who forsook baseball to become a golf professinoal, won the "Big Fore" invitational tournament at his home course today, beating Byron Nelson by a nine-stroke margin.
Vacant plots and dwellings in Brooklyn passed to new control in deals announced over the weekend.
BELMONT, Mass., June 24-- J. Franklin Ebersole, Professor of Banking and Finance at Harvard University, died today at his home here after a long illness. He was 60 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 24--A new system of price controls for wholesalers of household furniture and bedding will provide tighter and more enforceable rules and simplify compliance, the Office of Price Administration said tonight.

WEIMAR, Germany, June 24-- An atmosphere of anxiety and disquiet prevails in Thuringia. Somehow word had leaked out over this lush countryside with its ripening grain and fruit that the whole countryside as far west as Weimar was to be included in the Russian zone of occupation.

WASHINGTON, June 24--A compromise measure, to be approved in time to extend price control before the expiration of the present law six days from now and to represent substantial concessions from both the Democratic and Republican sides, was forecast tonight.
Administration leaders are planning to obtain Congressional approval of the Bretton Woods agreements before the summer recess.
A reappraisal of American arms and equipment, in the light of lessons learned in Europe, is of major importance as the decisive phase of the war against Japan opens.
OLYMPIA, Wash., June 24 (U.P.) --President Truman today joined members of the armed forces at near-by Fort Lewis in a prayer for a speedy victory and a lasting peace.

Despite heavy troop movements and civilian travel, the Central Railroad of New Jersey had a loss last year of nearly $6,000,000 on its passenger traffic, Shelton Pitney and Walter P. Gardner, trustees, said in their annual report for 1944.
SIMLA, India, June 25 (U.P.)--A conference of Indian leaders--but not including Mohandas K. Gandhi --took up British proposals for broadening India's self-government today.

A drive for $2,500,000, including $2,000,000 for study and development of air power and education of the public to "the necessity of adequate air strength in the maintenance of national security and the preservation of world peace," was started yesterday at a luncheon of the Air Power League in the Hotel Biltmore.

The average meal at home contains more meat and butter than that served in a public eating place, the nation's hotel and restaurant owners argued yesterday as they warned that a further cut in their ration allotments would ...

Faced with the necessity of turning out 40,000,000,000 board feet of lumber to supply all military and civilian needs in 1945, the hard-pressed lumber industry was waiting anxiously yesterday for word from a War Production Board lumber mission now in Europe.

After a year's lapse, the national professional tennis championship was renewed yesterday and thirtysix players, including the world-re newned William Tilden, started out at Rip's Courts on Park Avenue at Thirty-ninth Street.

BIRMINGHAM, England, June 25--Prime Minister Churchill plunged into the British election campagin in earnest today, driving 250 miles through the English midlands to the cheers of perhaps 100,000 people and the jeers of a handful who greeted the opening of his four-day 1,000-mile electioneering jaunt.

The light-metal age has begun. The era was launched when the War Production Board released 100,000,000 pounds of aluminum a quarter for civilian use two weeks ahead of the originally scheduled date of July 1.

Great mountains of war materials were consumed in the conquest of Okinawa--and "plenty more" must be prepared for even harder fights ahead--two soldiers and a young Marine officer warned here yesterday.

The 135 West Forty-second Street Corporation, of which Howard C. Hirsch is president, has sold the two-story business building at 135-139 West Forty-second Street to an investing client of Irving S. Wolper, broker in the transaction.

With incentive lacking, traders in cotton inclined yesterday to pursue a policy of watchful waiting, which was reflected in a modest turnover and narrow price swings in futures on the New York Cotton Exchange. After opening 2 points lower to 2 points higher than Saturday's final prices, the market drifted aimlessly and at close was 3 points lower to 2 points net higher.

DETROIT, June 25--CIO unionists who are embroiled with the AFL over a reconversion work dispute accepted conditionally tonight a peace formula and averted the immediate danger of a widespread walk-out.

Suspension of bus service to Orchard Beach in the Bronx next week-end unless an agreement is reached in the dispute between the Surface Transportation Company and the drivers was announced yesterday by Victor McQuistion, president of the company. The drivers are members of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

In a white and green floral setting yesterday afternoon at the River Club, Miss Mara di Zoppola, daughter of Countess Edith di Zoppola of New York and of Count Mario di Zoppola, was married to Lieut, Comdr. Richard T. Wharton, ...

ROME, June 25 (AP)--Allied occupation forces may move into sections of Vienna within three Weeks, with Gen. Mark W. Clark commanding United States units in the American zone of Austria, it was disclosed today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 25 (AP) --Neither rain, nor wind, nor lightning could slow Ohio State University's golf team today as the Buckeyes swept all honors in the first phase of the forty-eighth annual national collegiate golf tournament.

The number of volunteer assistants that the hospitals have lost since April totals as high as 50 per cent in some cases, Mrs. Frances Robinson, director of the United Hospital Fund's Volunteer Bureau, reported yesterday, in appealing for more workers.

WASHINGTON, June 25--The United States is continuing to supply lend-lease aid to Russisan Siberia, where "the possibility of Russia's entry into the war against Japan acts to pin down in northern Manchuria large numbers of Japanese troops," Leo T. Crowley, the Foreign Economic Administrator, has informed Congress.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (U.P.)-- Representative Leon H. Gavin, Republican, of Pennsylvania, told the House today that an air cadet under a hard labor sentence at the Army air base at Lincoln, Neb., was clubbed into unconsciousness by an M.P. last year because he was not breaking rocks fast enough. The blow, he added, knocked the fillings out of the cadet's teeth.

Remedial legislation to correct the present "muddled" tax status of research expenditures which now acts as a definite deterrent to new product development in the post-war period by private enterprises is called for by J. Keith Butters, ...

A proposal to restore unity in the ranks of American Zionists by ending the conflict between opposing camps represented by Dr. Stephen S. Wise, chairman of the American Zionist Emergency Council, and Dr. Abba Hillel Silver of Cleveland, who resigned as co-chairman ...

Reports were current yesterday in both the woolen goods and women's coat and suit industries that action by the War Production Board is imminent which may raise woolen goods purchase pri orities to the full 35 per cent of the 1943 base permitted under M-388. This figure had been cut to 50 per cent of the 35 per cent, or 17 per cent.

The conference of thirteen Governors on the food problem concluded that the situation may be seriously aggravated in the Northeastern States in the months ahead because of a shortage of adequate railroad facilities.

PARIS, June 25--Jacques Soustelle, Minister of Information, said today that the censorship to which foreign correspondents in France might be subjected after the dissolution of SHAEF would depend largely on what regulations were applied to French correspondents abroad.

Members of the People's Volunteer Corps who are to be assigned direct combat duty in the event of an invasion of the Japanese mainland have been warned that they will be under authority stemming from Emperor Hirohito and that they must "not allow themselves to be taken prisoner alive or die dishonorable deaths," the Japanese Domei agency said yesterday.

ROME, June 25--Press censorship in the Mediterranean theatre will henceforth apply only to "stuff that affects the Japanese war effort and not another thing," Brig. Gen. Arthur J. McChrystal, head of the information and censorship section of Allied Force Headquarters, said today.

Railroad shares again were the center of attraction in yesterday's trading on the New York Stock Exchange. They were followed closely by selected industrial issues. Transactions expanded slightly over the previous full session. The turnover was 1,890,000 shares, divided among the 948 individual issues in the trading.

ALBANY, June 25--Governor Dewey said today that the Fashion Institute of Technology and Design of New York City was, in a sense, a pioneer in the development of the State's program of schools of the applied and technical arts.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 (AP)--Senator Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, said today that he would sign the United Nations charter and would make "every effort to secure its ratification with reasonable speed."

WASHINGTON, June 25--The available supply of cotton textiles to be allocated in the third quarter to all claimants was estimated at approximately 225,000,000,000 yards today by officials of the War Production Board.

PARIS, June 25 (U.P.)--Units of the Ninth Air Force, the crack tactical fighter-bomber command which supported ground troops in Mediterranean and European fighting, head for the United States this week for redeployment to the Pacific, it was announced today.

CHICAGO, June, 25 (AP)--The yield from general sales, use and gross income taxes levied by twenty-three States set a new high mark of $745,000,000 in 1944, the Federation of Tax Administrators reported today.

WEIMAR, Germany, June 25 (U.P.) --The American occupation zone in Greater Berlin will be five districts in the south and southwest and will be the smallest of the three zones in the German capital, it was understood today.

GUAM, Tuesday, June 26--A semi-final count of Japanese casualties in the Okinawa campaign as of Monday shows that they have crossed the ll0,000 mark. Fleet Admiral Chester. W. Nimitz reported in his communique this morning a total of 110,549, of which 8,696 are prisoners of war.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP)-- Andrew J. Higgins, the shipbuilder, told the War Labor Board today that he would reopen contract negotiations with the New Orleans Metal Trades Council if workers chose the AFL unions in a plant election.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 25-- Alex Watson, veteran pro at Leewood, had a field day in the weekly one-day tournament of the Westchester P.G.A. at the Tamarack Country Club today.

A group composed of the Bankers Trust Company, the Boston Safe Deposit and Trust Company and the Day Trust Company of Boston bought yesterday $1,500,000 of Commonwealth of Massachusetts notes at 0.29 per cent. The obligations, dated July 11, 1945, will become payable on July 10, 1946.
Musicians of "Oklahoma!" have now decided to donate their services to the war bond campaign. Accordingly, a special matinee of the musical, previously canceled, will be held on July 10.
WASHINGTON, June 25--United States ship losses during the war against Germany and Italy were 105 vessels sunk and ten damaged.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 25-- Mrs. Imogene Dumas Stevens of 19 East Maple Street, New Canaan, 24-year-old wife of Maj. G. Ralsey Stevens 3d, engaged counsel today to defend her in the fatal shooting of Albert Kovacs, 19, a Navy seaman, late on Saturday night in a house next door to her home.

In a five-mile automobile chase in Brooklyn about 8:30 last night, in which several shots were fired by pursuing police but no one was hit, a stolen automobile containing two men was captured, and in the car police found a revolver taken from a policeman in a drug store hold-un on June 16.

BOSTON, June 25 (AP)--Cutting loose with a terrific two-fisted attack to the head at the opening bell, Tami Mauriello, 197, of New York knocked out Lou Nova, 203, of Los Angeles, Calif., in 2:47 of the first round of their scheduled 10-round feature boxing bout tonight before an estimated 8,000 crowd at Fenway Park.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 25-- Dick Haymes has been named as the singing lead and Ira Gershwin has been signed to write the lyrics for Twentieth Century-Fox's proposed musical "The Shocking Miss Pilgrim."
CHICAGO, June 25--Sixteen American airlines completed their 1944 operations without a single fatal accident, the National Safety Council reported today in announcing its 1944 aviation safety awards.

The former Italian luxury liner Saturnia, reconverted into the world's largest and speediest hospital ship, was taken over by the Army yesterday after a two-day shakedown cruise. Within a few days the vessel will leave the New York port and head for the Pacific, where her huge wards and latest medical equipment will receive their maximum use.

LONDON, June 25--Whether William Joyce--Lord Haw Haw, the German radio broadcaster--is a British, American or German subject will be argued in July at the old Bailey where Joyce will stand trial for high treason. His fate may hang an the answer.

To help blinded service men establish themselves as independent members of their home communities, 100 soldiers who lost their sight in World War II have organized a Blinded Veterans Association, the first of its kind in this country.

Frank B. Warren, general counsel of RCA Communications, Inc., a subsidiary of the Radio Corporation of America, died yesterday morning in New York Hospital. He was 48 years old. His home was at 1 Gracie Square.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP)-- The American Bankers Association, changing an earlier stand, endorsed the Bretton Woods monetary agreements today with a proviso for some changes. Previously it had opposed parts of them.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP)-- Secretary Ickes acceded today to a suggestion that the California tidelands suit be dismissed, and that action be taken in the Supreme Court to clear oil lands titles.

Construction of the proposed vehicular tunnel under the Narrows connecting Brooklyn and Staten Island is planned as "an essential facility warranted on the basis of national and State, as well as local, necessity," according to a final report of the New York City Tunnel Authority to Governor Dewey and the Legislature made public yesterday.

WITH THE THIRTY-SEVENTH (DIVISION, June 22 (Delayed)-- This division is rolling up the flatlands of the Cagayan Valley on northern Luzon, pushing deep into the last large section of the Philippines still in enemy hands even faster than it thrust into Manila four months ago.

Eight boys and girls who have had outstanding success in school work despite physical and other handicaps received yesterday citation and cash awards of more than $1,500. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, presented the ...

LONDON, June 25 (AP)--Rabbi J.H. Hertz, chief rabbi in Britain, said today in a letter to The Times that "a high percentage" of Jewish children saved from the Nazis in liberated lands have been baptized in the Christian faith by their rescuers.

PARIS, June 25--Now that the pressure of war is off and there is the definite prospect of national elections in the autumn, it is becoming more and more evident that there are strong tendencies for the various French political groups formerly united under the banner of resistance and national defense to break up, reclassify themselves and find their own levels in the post-war political scheme.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 25--President Truman told wounded soldiers here today that "in the next generation the veterans of this war are going to run this country. They fought to save it," he added, "now they want to fight to maintain it and that is their duty."

Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes, speaking last night at a dinner to Thomas Mann, Nobel prize winner in literature, assailed those who conduct a "whispering campaign" against Russia designed to make us "suspicious and nervous." Asking why we should prepare to fight our recent Ally, he declared that Russia's paramount need was for peace and that she had no reason for war with the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 25--Rent ceilings fixed by the Office of Price Administration for so-called "luxury" type housing in New York City were ruled inadequate today in a decision by the United States Emergency Court of Appeals.

WASHINGTON, June 25--The information given to the House Appropriations Committee by Leo T. Crowley, chief of the Foreign Economic Administration, that, on the recommendation of the President's "highest military advisers," we are still supplying lendlease to Russia, seemed to be received here with the greatest satisfaction today when the committee made it public.

MANILA, Tuesday, June 26--A gain up to six miles northward by the United States Thirty-seventh Infantry Division and a thrust southward by the Eleventh Airborne Division troops and guerrillas tightened a vise on an estimated 20,000 Japanese now "thoroughly trapped" in the Cagayan valley of northern Luzon, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

Stockholders of three companies at special meetings yesterday authorized creation of additional preferred shares for refinancing. Include were the Union Oil Company of California, E.R. Squibb Sons and the Hamilton Watch Company.

CHICAGO, June 25--Grain markets were unsettled today on the Board of Trade. Wheat, corn and rye broke early, hedging pressure being a factor in wheat. Corn was off on selling, induced by favorable weather over the week-end.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP)-- The Fish and Wildlife Service disclosed today that landings of fish in New York City have declined more than 50 per cent since 1938. No sea herring, swordfish, tuna, crabs or mussels came into the port in 1944.

The filing of an application with the Insurance Department of the State of New York for permission to organize a company to write fire and marine insurance was announced yesterday by A.F. Lafrentz, president of the American Surety Company.
Luck, which was all bad for William Helis a year ago, now seems to have switched as another of his fancy string came romping home in a stake race.

PARIS, June 25--Charles Luizet, Prefect of Police in Paris, promised the City Council today that American officers and Wacs would not be molested by "Paris' Finest" even when they tried to cross police lines during a big military parade.

WASHINGTON, June 25--Administration leaders in Congress were reported tonight to be seeking a consultation with President Truman on the eve of the SenateHouse conference on the bill to extend the Price Control Act, expires on Saturday.

CHUNGKING, China, June 25 (AP)--Chinese troops have clashed with strong Japanese forces fifteen miles northwest of Kweilin in a renewed drive to recapture that Kwangsi Province capital, once the biggest American air base in south-central China, the Chinese command said tonight.

RYE, N. Y., June 25--The marriage of Miss Sylvia Shethar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Burke Shethar of Milton Point, this place, to Lieut. (j. g.) Romeyn Everdell, USNR, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Everdell of Manhasset, L. I., took place here this afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Wendell W. Phillips.

JOPLIN, Mo., June 25 (AP)-- Twelve persons were killed and twenty-eight injured today when a bus, loaded with soldiers, struck a cow on Highway 71 four miles south, swerved from the highway, plunged down a ten-foot embankment and overturned.

OSWEGO, N.Y., June 25 (AP)-- Brig. Gen. William D'Dwyer, former executive director of the War Refugees Board, recommended today that the 969 European refugees at the Fort Ontario shelter here be allowed greater freedom pending a determination of their status.

As the Seventh War Loan, nicknamed the "Mighty Seventh," rolled past the $20,000,000,000 mark yesterday, Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. predicted that it would break all records established by previous war loans.

GUAM, Tuesday, June 26--Between 450 and 500 B-29's struck ten Japanese aircraft, ammunition and ordnance factories on Honshu about noon today in the largest demolition, pin-point mission ever flown against Japanese war-industry targets.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 (AP) --In the presence of President Truman, members of the American delegation to the United Nations Conference, lauded tonight the work of Secretary Stettinius as their chief and forecast many years of service ahead for him.

A woman passenger in an Amsterdam Avenue surface car was shot and seriously wounded and a man standing on a near-by sheet corner was slightly hurt, also by a bullet, at 8:20 o'clock last night as policemen fired a fusillade of pistol shots at an automobile driven by a man fleeing from questioners in front of the West 152d Street police station.
MANILA, Tuesday, June 26 (AP) --A series of hard aerial blows at the Japanese on Borneo and at many points throughout the Netherlands Indies was reported today by Gen. Douglas MacArthur.

CALCUTTA, India, June 25 (U.P.) --British troops in Burma have driven to within twenty-five miles of Mawchi, key strong point on the road to Thailand, a communique said today, as Allied planes pounded objectives in the Bangkok area, lower Burma and the Malay peninsula.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 25-- Delegates of the fifty United Nations, by rising vote of their chairmen, unanimously approved the final text of a global charter at 10:53 tonight and an audience of more than 3,000 in the War Memorial Opera House jumped to its feet to cheer and applaud for a full minute.

MOSCOW, June 25--The German Communist party, in a manifesto issued in Berlin, today rejected a soviet system for present-day Germany and instead asked for a coalition parliamentary government and the development of private enterprise and the profit system.
The prototype of the modern submarine, with its internal combustion engines for surface cruising and its electric motors for subsurface propulsion, was the invention of John P. Holland.

More than 4,000 Marines died on Iwo Jima. It was a tragic price to pay for eight square miles of bleak volcanic rock. Yet it is clear enough now that these men died that their fighting comrades might live. Since March 4 the record shows that 821 B-29's, carrying 9,361 trained American fliers who would almost certainly have been lost at sea, have made emergency landings on this tiny island of refuge.

There can be no secure peace in American industry for working men and women, for employers or for the public until "race prejudice is licked," Malcolm Ross, chairman of the Fair Employment Practices Committee, declared last night before a crowd estimated at 20,000 at the third annual Negro Freedom Rally in Madison Square Garden.

Sir Alexander Fleming, discoverer of penicillin, said last night that a better method of administering the drug than by injection every two or three hours as at present was needed to extend its use. The British scientist warned, however, in speaking at a dinner in his honor in the Hotel WaldorfAstoria, that administration by mouth would lead to "self-medication and all its abuses."

Representatives of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, an independent organization, and of the Publishers Association of New York City conferred all day yesterday at the association's offices, 1475 Broadway, on the union's demands for wage increases and other readjustments and adjourned without reaching an agreement. The union has scheduled a strike vote for Friday.

WILMINGTON, N.C., June 25 (AP)--The tropical storm, attended by dangerous winds, brushed up the South and North Carolina coast lines today, doing no serious damage on the basis of early reports, but carrying a threat to shipping and residents of exposed places.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25-- Commonwealth Utilities Corporation's proposed sale of interest in the Arizona Power Corporation, to James C. Tucker, president of the Arizona Electric Corporation, was approved today in a 4-to-1 decision of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 25-- President Truman received a wildly enthusiastic ovation this afternoon from San Franciscans, who turned out in record numbers for their first chance to see the new President of the United States.

For the longest while ti seemed as though the Brooklyn Dodgers were reaching out for nothing more tangible than a mirage as they struck out boldly for the Pennant oasis. Now, however, even the experts are not sure.

Of all governmental wartime controls, price regulation should be relinquished with the greatest caution, according to The Guaranty Survey for June, published by the Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation is preparing a registration statement to be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering a proposed issue of $75,000,000 of new consolidated mortgage bonds. The bonds, it is understood, will carry a 2 per cent coupon and mature in twenty-five years.

BUENOS AIRES, June 25--Charges of extraordinarily brutal treatment of political prisoners have been made against the national gendarmerie in the territory of Chaco, in the extreme north of Argentina, it was revealed today.
DUBLIN, June 25--Dublin was gaily bedecked today with flowers and flags for the inauguration of Sean T. O'Kelly, former Deputy Premier, as the second President of Eire.

Further readjustments in price differences between old and new crop cotton futures were made yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Closing prices were 11 points lower for July and 1 to 9 points higher for the new-crop deliveries than on Monday.

Wait A Bit, William Ziegler Jr.'s chestnut home, who last June was involved in the astounding triple dead heat with Brownie and Bosseut in the Carter Handicap at the same track, made his first start of the year yesterday at Aqueduct.

Both local entrants in the National League, the Giants and Dodgers, are all set--they hope-- to turn back the invasion of the Polo Grounds and Ebbets Field, respectively, by the strong western clubs, starting today.

Priorities will be in this order; official calls, authorized press calls, armed forces calls and civilian calls.

The Irving Trust Company reported yesterday that operating income for the six months ended June 30, 1945, was $8,832,743, compared with $7,502,940 for the first half of 1944. This report initiated a new policy on the part of the Irving in issuing a mid-year earnings report.

GUAM, Tuesday, July 10--A great fleet of Superfortresses totaling 500 to 600 bombers flew a record fire and demolition mission over Honshu early today against targets stretching along more than half of that main Japanese home island.

SIMLA, India, July 9--The Moslem League's restated insistance on nominating all the Moslem members of the proposed Indian Central Government carried the conference of Indian political leaders to the verge of collapse today.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP)-- Citing inflationary dangers, the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System has rejected a proposal to exempt veterans from wartime credit restrictions on installment purchases.

The ultimatum served yesterday by the War Labor Board upon the striking Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, ordering the strikers to return to work at 8 A.M. tomorrow, threatens to impose the severest sanctions yet resorted to by the board, to enforce obedience to its authority.
PARIS, July 9--Some of the world's most famous paintings appeared today at a limited reopening of the Louvre with a splendor of color that has not been seen for centuries.

ROME (By Air Courier)--In Yugoslavia, a land of strange contrasts, the strangest contrast of all at present is the one between what they say they want to do and what they seem to be doing.

President Truman was many hundred of miles out in the Atlantic yesterday, on his way to the Big Three meeting in Berlin, when the Senate Foreign Relations Committee opened its hearings on the United Nations Charter.

Joseph S. Maxwell of 229 Greenway South, Forest Hills, Queens, a senior vice president in the commercial banking department of the New York Trust Company, died yesterday morning in the New York Hospital after an illness of several months.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP)-- The Treasury is seriously considering action which would save each member of Congress at least $1,000 a year in income taxes.
BERLIN, July 10--A new party has appeared in Berlin under Russian occupation rules, which, unlike the American and British regulations, permit the revival of German political activity.

A record for westbound troop movement will be set today when three of the Atlantic's biggest transports and five smaller craft land 35,000 American and Canadian troops at Army embarkation ports in New York harbor.

The housewives of Bayside, Queens, were up in arms yesterday over the fining of four of their number to the tune of $4 each for overtime parking while they were performing that nowadays slightly magical feat of bringing home the bacon.
HOLLYWOOD, July 10 (U.P.)-- Barbara Hutton filed suit for divorce today against Actor Cary Grant, and charged that he caused her "grievous mental distress, suffering and anguish."
LONDON, July 10--All signs today point to heavy gains for the Labor party in the general election, with a real chance that the Liberals will hold the balance of power.

GUAM, Wednesday, July 11-- Preliminary reports from yesterday's all-out air attack on the Japanese home islands, in which as many as 2,000 United States Navy, Army and Marine aircraft may have participated, showed the destruction or damage of 173 enemy planes and thirty-one enemy ships.

Wilton Simpson (Bill) Farnsworth, boxing writer columnist and promoter, and for twenty-three years the sports editor of two Hearst newspapers here died early yesterday in St. Clare's Hospital, 415 West Fifty-first Street, from the effects of a cerebral hemorrhage he suffered last autumn. His age was 60.

Plans for the proposed $42,000,000 wholesale produce market in lower Manhattan will be presented "very shortly" to the Board of Estimate, Henry M. Brundage, Commissioner of Markets, announced yesterday in a speech before the executive board of the Mercantile Exchange.

ABOARD A UNITED STATES CRUISER, July 10--President Truman was on the mid-Atlantic today aboard this ship, bound for a northern European port. There he will board a plane for Potsdam, Berlin suburb, for the conference next week with Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Stalin.

WASHINGTON, July 10--The United States Navy controls the sea right up to Japan's shoreline, James V. Forrestal, Secretary of the Navy, and other Navy spokesmen said today in hailing the effect and significance of Admiral Wiliam F. Halsey's air strikes against Tokyo.
Strikes raised the total of idle in labor disputes to more than 55,475 yesterday, but before the end of the day at least 1,000 had returned to work.

Two of the three elaborate musicals, all touched up here and there for present-day audiences and revived by Edwin Lester in behalf of the Los Angeles and San Francisco Civic Light Opera Associations, were so highly regarded that the pair has been snapped up by other managements.
Hailed as the first antique show to be held in the summer in the metropolitan district, the Mount Vernon Antique Fair opened yesterday afternoon at the Westchester Women's Club. Mount Vernon.

CHUNGKING, China, July 10 (AP)--Chinese troops have isolated Japanese-held Kanhsien, a former American air base 200 miles north of Hong Kong, and have hurled a strong flank attack against enemy beachheads on China's southeast "invasion" coast below Amoy, the Chinese High Command said today.

LONDON, July 10--Dr. Leo Baeck, the last Chief Rabbi of Germany, who spent several years in German concentration camps, said today that the Allies must give the people of good-will left in Germany a "view and vision" of the future and must punish every criminal "quickly, immediately and without mercy."

Guy W. Vaughan, president of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, informed stockholders in the annual report released today that 1944 shipments of aircraft, engines and propellers totaling $1,716,935,176 were 32.5 per cent above the previous year, exceeded the dollar volume output of any other aircraft company and set a new high record for the industry.

WASHINGTON, July 10--Dr. Oscar Ibarra Garcia, Argentine Ambassador, gave assurances today of the intention of his Government to cooperate fully with the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 10--The War and Navy Departments announced today 550 Army and 338 Navy casualties, respectively. Also made public were the names of seventy-six Army personnel freed from German prison camps.

DAYTON, Ohio, July 10 (AP)-- Byron Nelson, the man with the miseries in his back, made his "last chance" good today and scored a spectacular eagle on the seventeenth hole to wind up in a tie with Johnny Revolta of Evanston, Ill., for the medal in the twenty-seventh annual professional championship golf tournament.

Three French labor leaders warned here yesterday that, unless their country's industry received immediate aid in the form of American raw materials and machine tools as well as the use of 80,000 German war prisoners to work in coal mines, France faces a serious economic crisis that will cause 1,000,000 persons to lose their jobs by October.

Widener's Polynesian, making his first start since he won the Preakness Stakes at Pimlico last month, fell by the wayside at Aqueduct yesterday in the nineteenth running of the $11,900 Shevlin Stakes, a prep for the $50,000 added Dwyer Stakes on the Queens County Jockey Club's closing program Saturday.

Heavy, bomber and fighter units, continuing the neutralization of Formosa, struck at grounded enemy planes and airdrome installations at Shinchiku and attacked oil fields on the southwest coastal plain. A night patrol plane harassed the enemy base at Mako in the Pescadores.

The 783 Holding Corporation has sold to a client of Samuel Katz the three-story business building at 783 Eighth Avenue, 25 by 100 feet, assessed at $81,000. John Avlon was the broker and Joseph V. Costa was attorney for the sellers.

CHICAGO, July 10--If employment is to reach a satisfactory level after the war, business must plan for production 30 to 45 per cent greater than in any peacetime year, Walter D. Fuller, chairman of the Committee for Economic Development, field development division, said today at a meeting of the CED's trustees.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10--Despite the objections of some of the prominent Biddies, Abraham Bitle, a Russian-born bartender, and his wife, Celie, today became, with the approval of Judge Eugene Alessandroni in the Common Pleas Court, Abraham and Celie Biddle.

CHICAGO, July 10--Brokers on the Board of Trade, today placed a decidedly bullish construction on the Department of Agriculture's estimate of the corn crop for this year, the figures suggesting the smallest harvest since 1941, with the stock on farms on July 1, although considerably larger than a year ago, the smallest since 1938.
The stock market continued yesterday to eliminate part of its recent losses, but gains which ran to a point and beyond were slightly shaded before the close.

The 515-pound broadbill swordfish that Hans Hinrichs of Quogue, L.I., caught last week off Long Island is believed to be an Atlantic rod-and-reel record, but efforts yesterday to establish it definitely as such failed.

WASHINGTON, July 10--In an effort "to clear the air" of rumors of Japanese peace feelers, Joseph C. Grew, Acting Secretary of State, today issued a statement saying the United States had received no peace feelers from anyone who could speak for the Japanese Government. He reaffirmed this Government's determination to crush Japanese militarism on the basis of unconditional surrender.

NEW LONDON, N.H., July 10 (AP)--Maj. Gen. Fred W. Sladen, retired Army officer, died in a hospital here today at the age of 78. A son of Major Joseph A. Sladen, the general was born in Massachusetts and was graduated from the United States Military Academy in 1890.

WASHINGTON, July 10--New types of warships are evolving as a result of offensive lessons taught by enemy aircraft during this war, Vice Admiral Edward L. Cochrane, chief of the Bureau of Ships, said today.
