BERLIN, July 10--The Russian soldiers one meets and talks with in the streets of the German capital are friendly and full of curiosity about America and its people.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 10--Adolf Hitler never fooled Sweden, Foreign Minister Christian E. Guenther aid today in an interview. "We knew perfectly well that Hitler had resolved to settle the Swedish problem by launching a lightning attack on Sweden in February, 1942," he asserted.
A king was ready to abdicate in favor of a queen yesterday at the Children's Aid Society's Avenue B center playground at 549 East Sixteenth Street.

WASHINGTON, July 10-- Spokesmen for 16,000 striking employes of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company of Akron refused today to accede to the request of the War Labor Board to recommend that the strikers return to work and permit the orderly procedure of the board to operate.

PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., July 10 --A severe electrical storm, in which the damage from rain, hail, wind and lightning was increased by resulting flash floods, killed at least six persons last night in communities along the Lehigh Valley.

ST. LOUIS, July 10 (AP)--The American League champion Browns paraded nine pitchers to the mound tonight and the nine proceeded to blank the world champion Cardinals, 3 to 0, on two hits before 24,113 fans at a War Fund charity exhibition contest.

Two items of news in yesterday's papers have a bearing on American peace policy as direct as the Senate hearings on the United Nations Charter. One is that the redeployment of Uncle Sam's forces in Europe is far ahead of schedule.

WASHINGTON, July 10--Before a crowd of 23,791 fans, who enriched the American Red Cross and the War Fund to the extent of $22,760, the Dodgers dropped a 4-3 decision to the Senators under the lights at Griffith Stadium tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP)-- The automobile industry will present to the War Production Board tomorrow a list of more than forty-five material controls which still stand as obstacles to the production of passenger cars.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10 (AP)-- The Phillies won the city championship tonight, defeating their American League rivals, the Athletics, 7-6, in a National War Fund game. A total of 4,835 fans paid approximately $5,000.

Fears of a short American cotton crop and increased number of weevil complaints from the Cotton Belt brought in yesterday a buying movement in the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange that carried prices to new highs for the season for all months except old July. Closing prices were at net gains of 1 to 21 points.

Officials of fourteen local Public Housing Authorities sold yesterday a total of $36,353,000 of temporary-loan notes at interest rates ranging from 0.41 per cent to 0.49 per cent. The obligations will mature on Aug. 6 and Aug. 27, 1946.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 10 --Now that Westchester County, the State and the Federal Government have agreed to tolls on Westchester's Hutchinson River and Saw Mill River Parkways, no taxpayer has legal cause or justifiable reason to complain about the levies, special counsel for the count ty contended here today in Supreme Court.
BUENOS AIRES, July 10--An unidentified German submarine of 700 tons surrendered at 7:30 o'clock this morning to Argentine naval authorities at the submarine base of Mar del Plata.

ROME, July 10--In his greeting to Herbert H. Lehman, the director general, and other officials of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration yesterday, Pope Pius furthered his recently recurrent theme that the menace of totalitarianism remains despite the end of the war and declared it was "no wonder" that many "right-hearted" men were anxious about the future.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP)-- Details of an alleged off-the-record split of $240,000 in a receivership case were related today at a House judiciary subcommittee investigation of former Federal Judge Albert W. Johnson of Pennsylvania's middle district.

Herbert Flam, 16-year-old Beverly Hills, Calif., high school student, who is seeded No. 1, gained the semi-final round of the Eastern junior singles championship by vanquishing James L. Bicknell of Garden City, L.I., 9-7, 7--5 at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, yesterday.

A large group of underwriters headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will offer today to the public $34,000,000 of the Portland General Electric Company's first mortgage 3 1/8 per cent bonds, due in 1975. The bonds will be priced at 102.41 per cent and accrued interest from July 1.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10--The Appalachian Electric Power Company and the Ohio Power Company, both subsidiaries of the American Gas and Electric Company, were granted permission by the SEC to use excess cash in their treasuries to acquire and cancel outstanding gold debentures.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 10--Food for Yugoslavia has begun to arrive through the port of Trieste with the arrival of the first United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration ship Jesse Billingsley, it was announced here today.

WASHINGTON, July 10(AP)-- Pickets of the National Maritime Union, CIO, in a national protest against a reduction in seamen's bonuses, paraded today in front of the Commerce Department Building housing the office of Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, War Shipping Administrator.

Steel production in the United States in the first haif of 1945 amounted to 43,180,223 net tons, the lowest for the period since the first half of 1942, but two-thirds of total production in the entire year 1929, the record peacetime production year, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (U.P.)-- The first night flying from ABY flat-top aircraft carriers was done on the Atlantic last year to combat the German submarine menace, the Navy reported today.
WITH THE UNITED STATES THIRD FLEET, off Tokyo, July 10 --More than 1,000 carrier-based planes of Admiral William F. Halsey's Third Fleet struck today against airfields in the Tokyo area.

The estate of Constance Sloan has sold the four-story residence with rear garden at 214 East Sixty-second Street to a client of Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., who will alter and occupy it. The assessed value is $25,000.

BOSTON, July 10 (AP)--All that remained of baseball's canceled All-Star game--the feature act, a pitching-batting duel between Boston's Dave (Boo) Ferriss and Tommy Holmes--thrilled a crowd of 22,809 on the original Fenway Park stage today as the Red Sox defeated the Braves, 8--1, in their war fund intracity exhibition.

WASHINGTON, July 10--The Seventh War Loan went over its $14,000,000,000 goal by more than $12,000,000,000, Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, announced tonight in a triumphal radio address that was, in effect, his "valedictory" as Secretary.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 10--The situation in the Levant appears to have eased as a result of the French proposal to place a force of some 25,000 "troopes speciales," recruited locally and considered as a part of the French Army, under Syrian and Lebanese control.
Officials of two railroads and a public utility company accepted bids from underwriting groups yesterday for new bond issues aggregating $20,655,000.
LONDON, July 10--Communist Russia was pictured in the role of international banker offering dollar credits to neighboring states in reports widely accepted here today.

FORT DEVENS, Mass., July 10 --Pvt. Joseph V. McGee, who was released from a two-year sentence for slapping a German prisoner-ofwar in France, was stripped of a hero's role today as a court-martial sentenced him to six months at hard labor.
SIMLA, India, July 10--Pessimism was rife in Simla today as hopes for a successful outcome of the conference of Indian political leaders faded.

There's a peculiar depth to a summer night after a day-long rain, a depth of sensation as well as of distance and darkness. The earth is drenched. The night breeze is almost palpable, for it is the heavy damp air in motion.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27-- Amid billows of dust and a roar heard a mile away, the front wall of the 82-year-old Central North Broad Street Presbyterian Church collapsed at 4:55 o'clock this morning, piling rubble twenty feet high on the pavement at Broad and Green Streets.

ROME, July 27--While the Cabinet met this evening to examine the international situation in view of the election results in Great Britain, the British Labor party victory continued foremost in the minds of all Italians, who realize just how crucial this winter will be in the nation's history.
Paul W. Bradford, former assistant to the director of the Foreign Economic Administration, has been appointed general manager of American Express Company operations for Great Britain and Eire.

WASHINGTON, July 27--War workers, tired and dissatisfied with existing provisions for unemployment relief, are leaving aircraft plants so fast that it is threatening production and the total output probably will fall below levels scheduled for this month, J.A. Krug, chairman of the War Production Board, stated today.

As tomorrow is the 170th anniversary of the founding of the Chaplain Corps of the United States Army, the Rev. George J. Zentgraf, Second Service Command chaplain with the rank of colonel, requested yesterday that all chaplains in the Service Command dedicate the day to the memory of the 104 chaplains who thus far have lost their lives in World War II.

WASHINGTON, July 27--The Administration wound up its case on the United Nations Security Charter today and decided to ask both Houses of Congress to approve, by a simple majority vote, a joint resolution putting specified military forces at the disposal of the new League of Nations.

LONDON, July 27 (U.P.)--Winston Churchill paid his last visit as a tenant to 10 Downing Street, official residence of Prime Ministers, tonight and was cheered by a waiting crowd, many of whom had waited two hours or more to see him. He left shortly before 9 A.M. giving the V-sign to the crowd.

Mrs. Louisa Hoar La Farge, wife of the poet, Christopher R. LONDON, Aug. 21 (AP)--With sudden Russian support, a resolution to send relief to Italy and Austria was passed by a 31-to-1 vote today in a committee meeting of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration.

MOSCOW, Aug. 21--After the United Nations Charter had been ratified yesterday, Izvestia repeated today the familiar hopes that the Charter, in contrast with the League of Nations, might restrain aggression throughout the world.
Elimination of wartime restrictions on bus service and restoration of the two-block stop in place of the present four-block "skip" is expected by Saturday, the Police Department announced yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 21--Viscount Wavell, Viceroy of India, is coming to London soon to discuss new steps to be taken with regard to India. At the same time New Delhi announced that general elections to the central and provincial legislatures in British India will be held as soon as possible.

As soon as reconversion is completed, New York City should be ablel to offer its workers 500,000 more jobs than before the war, according to a statement yesterday by James A. Farley, chairman of the New York City Committee for Economic Development.
STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 21-- James Cowie of Los Angeles today showed on Long Island Sound how he had won the Star Class international championship in a sea jump off San Diego five years ago.

BOSTON, Aug. 21 (AP)--Charles (Red) Barrett today pitched his eighteenth victory of the season and his second straight over his former Braves' teammates by hurling the Cardinals to an 8-4 conquest in their 1945 Boston finale

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 21 (AP)--The Browns could only manage a split in their double header tonight with the Red Sox, but moved into a tie for third place in the American League with Chicago, who dropped a double-header to New York. The Browns won the first game, 2 to 1, and lost the second, 4 to 3, in a contest called after five innings because Of rain.
Armed with her prize-winning commercial art sketches, Miss Frances L. Chandler returned yesterday to the Children's Aid Society, 105 East Twenty-second Street, where she had her first start.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21--Despite the flood of war contract cancellations which has hit the nation's industries during the past few weeks, authorities in the machine tool industry reported today that comparatively few equipment orders have been terminated.

PARAMUS, N. J., Aug. 21--Mrs. Archie McLave of the Hudson River Country Club took the third women's Metropolitan Golf Association tournament to be held in New Jersey this year when she posted 87--13--74 at the Ridgewood Country Club.
The market for shares in the New York Stock Exchange moved yesterday over an erratic course, but as buyers utilized each nonpressure period to support the list final prices were on a rallying tone.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. L, Aug. 21 --Armand L. Bruneau, veteral tennis player, a well-known figure in the game for many years, and a former runner-up for the National Veterans Championship, was found dead in bed here yesterday at the Mansard Inn. Hampton Road.

LONDON, Aug. 21(AP)--The abrupt termination of lend-lease and a parliamentary warning that without American aid the empire's "standard of life is bound to fall," tonight heightened Britain's concern over her economic future.

The biggest bass the writer has heard of this season came out of Hemlock Reservoir the other evening. It was a large-mouth that weighed an even eight pounds and was caught on a jitter-bug plug by Edward Burke of Carmel, N. Y., a water inspector for New York City.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 21 (AP)-- Cleveland nudged Washington along toward first place in the American League today, adding two errors to a fifteen-hit barrage by the Senators to give the capital city crew an 11-to-8 victory and four out of five for the series.

Japanese Imperial Headquarters and the Japanese Government issued a joint communiqu yesterday announcing that the landing of Allied occupation troops on the Japanese mainland would begin next Sunday, the Japanese Domei agency reported.

New York is planning another rousing official welcome for General de Gaulle on Monday after he has completed his talks with Mr. Truman, it became known yesterday after a conference among Mayor La Guardia, Grover A. Whalen, the city's unofficial host, and a hastily summoned reception committee.
Having put the Dodgers through the wringer on "wash-day" by trouncing them, 11-1, Frankie Frisch's Pirates yesterday hung 'em out to dry as they bade farewell to Ebbets Field for 1945.

Foreign Secretay Bevin's statement to the House of Commons on Monday showed, as was expected, that the Labor party's victory had not revolutionized British foreign policy. Mr. Bevin's predecessor, Anthony Eden, found nothing to criticize. He went further. He said that he and Mr. Bevin had never disagreed about foreign policy during their four years together in the Coalition Cabinet.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 21 (AP) --The Army's Silver Star for gallantry in action, awarded posthumously to Pfc. William S. Moore dr., 24, grandson of the late Joseph Pulitzer, founder of The St. Louis Post-Dispatch, was presented to his mother, Mrs. Edith Pulitzer Moore of New York and Bar Harbor.

The B. F. Goodrich Company reported yesterday for the first half of 1945 a consolidated net income of $5,621,544, equal to 2.52 per cent of net sales of $222,530,675. This compared with $5,244,308 equal to 2.54 per cent of net sales of $206,273,349, for the same six months of 1944.

Stephenson, executive vice president of the National Shoe Manufacturers Association, said yesterday.

With the dissolution of the League of Nations the fate of millions of displaced European Jews will become the concern of the United States, former Senator Guy M. Gillette, president of the American League for a Free Palestine, declared yesterday.

Plans for a World Christian Conference for Palestine in Washington on Nov. 1 and 2 to coordinate world-wide Christian support of Zionist aspirations were announced yesterday by Dean Howard M. Le Sourd of Boston University and Dr. Carl Hermann Voss, co-directors of the American Christian Palestine Committee.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21--Maj. Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, who recently relinquished his command of the 101st Airborne Division, will become superintendent of the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y., on Sept. 1, the War Department announced today.

ROME. Aug. 21-Eleven Congressional committeemen who recently visited Russia were received today by the Pope, who told them that what St. Paul said of the human body also applied to the international body politic: "If one member suffers, all the members suffer with it."

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Aug. 21--There are 14,433,752 people in the American occupation zone of Germany, according to a compilation of sectional estimates, the reports and statistics branch of G-5, USFBT, announced today.

LONDON, Aug, 21--A group of Labor members in the House of Commons challenged the British Government tonight over its policy on the atomic bomb by filing a motion calling for an international organization to control the new weapon, after Prime Minister...

LOON LAKE, N. Y., Aug. 21-- Governor Dewey announced today that the State has agreed to purchase the $3,600,000 Metropolitan Life Insurance Sanitarium in the foothills of the Adirondacks for $350,000, and that it will be used as a rest camp for returning New York veterans.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, Aug. 21 --Three members of the Juvenile squad competing in the annual tournament for the championship of the New York State Chess Association were successful today in the fourth round.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP)-- As protests over dispatch of combat veterans to the Pacific reached the White House, it was learned today that the War Department had ordered that no enlisted man with seventy-five or more discharge points be sent overseas, unless he volunteers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21--Fear sprang up among members of the House today that, should that body dash back in full force from its peace-shortened recess on Sept. 5, as now scheduled, it might find little, if anything, to do.

LONDON, Wednesday, Aug. 22 (AP)--In a broadcast from New Delhi, Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten called on the commander of the Japanese southern army in Burma today to "confirm" that all hostilities by his troops will cease today, as Japanese Imperial Headquarters recently indicated.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 21 (AP)--Directors of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company voted today to submit a proposal to the boards of the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate), Pere Marquette and Wheeling Lake Erie Railway Companies for a merger of the four roads through an exchange of stock.

PARIS, Aug. 21--While refraining from openly opposing the Government, the Radical Socialist convention here devoted its second session today to advocating that the Fourth Republic should be a continuation of the Third.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 21 --The measure drawn up by the Finnish Government of Premier Juho K. Paasikivi creating the new special court for trial of those responsible for Finland's war policy was signed by President Baron Carl Gustav Mannerheim today, according to information from Helsinki.

The five-story building at 1146 Intervale Avenue, the Bronx, containing three stores and thirty-two apartments, has been sold by City Estates, Inc., to Herbert Butler. The property, assessed at $49,000, was sold subject to a mortgage of $16,000 and a purchase money mortgage of $14,000. Louis Zucker Co. were the brokers.

The blaze that swept upper stories of the Empire State Building after an Army bomber tore through it, spewing burning gasoline over ten floors of the thousand-foot structure, was "an easy fire" because city fire-fighting forces were fully prepared for such an emergency, Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh explained yesterday in his official report on the tragedy that claimed fourteen lives.

As a part of its program to provide a greater measure of comfort and privacy for elderly persons of limited means, the Home for Aged and Infirm Hebrews yesterday announced the purchase of a ninestory apartment house at 302 West Eighty-seventh Street.

Meatless Tuesdays and Fridays which Mayor La Guardia said only last week could not be dropped at this time, are being ignored by two of every five public eating places in New York, Paul Henkel, president of the Society of Restaurateurs, complained yesterday.

The problem of what is to become of families that have been living in Federally constructed wartime housing projects now that many of them are being discharged in war plants is providing a new kind of headache for Government land local agencies.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21--Reconversion "profit factors" for eight classes of consumer and industrial goods were established today by the Office of Price Administration for use by manufacturers in determining adjustments in current ceiling prices for items about to be put on the market after a wartime absence.

An investing client of the Duross Company, brokers, bought from the Edgert Realty Corporation the six-story twenty-four-family apartment building known as the Chautauqua at 330-34 West Fifteenth Street, on a plot 50 by 80 feet between Eighth and Ninth Avenues. The property is assessed.

The first full biography of Conrad Weiser, Pennsylvania frontiersman of the Colonial period will be published Sept. 12 by the University of Pennsylvania Press. Weiser was a man of many talents and interests--farmer, soldier, churchman, political leader--but he is chiefly significant as the great champion of the Indians of the Six Nations.

Reporting on the six weeks' operation of its three-year plan to place war veterans in jobs in advertising and related fields, the Advertising Club of New York disclosed yesterday that 256 ex-service men have registered at its placement office.
CHICAGO, Aug. 21--Grain markets fluctuated in a nervous manner today on the Board of Trade, an early break carrying the May and July deliveries of leading grains to new seasonal lows.

FULDA, Germany, Aug. 21--In this bomb-damaged village, for centuries a seat of Roman Catholicism in Germany, eighteen bishops this morning opened their annual thirty-day conference with solemn prayers at the tomb of St. Boniface in the cathedral of Fulda.

THE news announcement probably made much more of a stir in Cleveland than New York. It merely stated that Rapid Robert Feller would return to the Indian line-up this week and might even be pitching by Friday. Wow! That's really something.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21--Despite President Truman's appeal to organized labor that it continue its no-strike pledge into the post-war period, two large unions announced today that they had revoked their pledge and "would immediately campaign for wage increases for their members."

The first group of Allied landing forces to occupy the Japanese mainland will land on a portion of the mainland around metropolitan Tokyo, Chiga, the Kanagawa [Kana River], Yamanashi and Shizudoka Prefectures, beginning Aug. 26.

KEARNY, N. J., Aug. 21Frederic Arthur Gainard, captain in charge of ship trials and deliveries at the United States Steel Corporation's Federal shipyard here and at Port Newark, N. J., since Nov. 1, 1942, died last night at his home, 5 Park Avenue, West Orange, N. J., after an illness of two months. His age was 85.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21--Failure of the United States to provide full employment for its citizens "will certainly affect and may even determine the direction of the world's political and economic development," James F. Byrnes, Secretary of State, today told a Senate group ,investigating how to maintain such American employment in the post-war pe riod.
DETROIT, Aug. 21 (U.P.)--Thousands of works lured to this arsenal city by the big pay of war plants were taking the long road home tonight.

KAVALLA, Greece, Aug. 21-- Beaten though she had been, Bulgaria, ancient foe of Hellenism that thrice in this century has sought to deprive Greece of her Macedonian province, is again a source of danger, according to prevalent opinion. For Bulgaria is believed to be in the closest alliance with Yugoslavia, which lately has adopted a menacing attitude toward Greece.

MANILA, Aug. 21--With its envoys safely back in Tokyo after receiving Gen. Douglas MacArthur's surrender orders, the Japanese Government today intensified its efforts to prepare the Japanese public for an American landing, with the Tokyo radio making a special appeal to the suicide flier organization, the Kamikazes, to give in.

The War Production Board is to be congratulated on the speed with which it is removing production controls. Particularly gratifying is the quickness with which it has taken off limits on the number of radios, refrigerators, stoves, electric fans, trucks and a long list of other items which manufacturers are permitted to produce.
OSLO, Norway, Aug. 21 (AP)-- Quisling, stuttering and nervous, whispered a hoarse "No" today to a question from Judge Solem whether German Admiral Raeder had asked him to "betray your country."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21--President Truman revoked today a three-year-old executive order providing premium pay for war workers remaining on the job on national holidays.

LONDON, Aug. 21--The tone of the stock markets here was steady today, but the turnover was restricted, apparently by a desire of traders to await the statement of the Chancellor of the Exchequer on the Government's financial policy in the House of Commons.

LAKE FOREST, Ill., Aug. 21 (AP) --The defending champion, Miss Dorothy Germain of Philadelphia, and the medalist, Miss Louise Suggs of Atlanta, paced their respective brackets to first-round triumphs in the forty-fifth women's Western amateur golf championships over the rain-deluged Knollwood Club course today.
Residential properties, a restaurant building and a motion picture theatre were among the East Side properties figuring in realty transactions yesterday.

MANILA, Aug. 21--The Japanese Government today informed the Supreme Allied Commander that representations of the Swiss Legation in Tokyo, requesting that a delegation of the International Red Cross be permitted to administer to war prisoners, had been granted and that preparations for this purpose were under way.
LONDON, Aug. 21--Five hundred enemy vessels were sunk by the "little ships" of the British Navy's coastal forces during the European war.

DETROIT, Aug. 21 (AP)--Louis (Bobo) Newsom, as advertised, pitched both ends of a twin bill for the Athletics today but the Tigers knocked him out of the box twice, winning the nightcap, 7 to 6, with a ninth-inning rally after losing the first game by the same score in eleven innings.

GUAM, Aug. 21--American air and sea power blasted all but fiftyfive combat ships of Japan's once formidable navy out of the Pacific war and reduced her great merchant fleet to little more than 1,000,000 tons, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today on the basis of information given by Japanese surrender envoys in Manila.
WASHINGTON" Aug. 21--NyIon hose by Christmas, if not by Thanksgiving, and in plentiful quantity to supply the war-sharpened demand, was today's official prediction by the War Production Board.

In accord with its promise of 1940 that Netherlands nationals in this country who enlisted in the Dutch Army would be demobilized here instead of abroad, the military bureau of the Netherlands Consul General has begun to bring back the "several hundred" men it recruited in the United States, it was disclosed yesterday. The procedure will take six to eight months.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21--The virtual end of controls over all construction, the last major industry to be under wartime restrictions, suddenly came into view today as the War Production Board dropped its ban against industrial building and simultaneously revealed plans first to relax drastically, and soon to abandon altogether, its order limiting the use of lumber.

The Elinor and Henry Morgenthau Jr. Foundation for Peace, Inc., an educational and charitable organization named after the former Secretary of the Treasury and his wife, has been organized, it was announced yesterday by Harper Brotohers publishing house, which expects to bring out Mr. Morgenthau's book, "Germany Is Our Problem," on Oct. 17.

PARIS, Aug. 21--Contending that the Provisional Government is deliberately restricting newsprint rations for political purposes and thus reducing the freedom of editorial expression and the circulation of independent opinion before the elections, the French press is now engaged in a determined struggle to obtain greater facilities. Should this fail, it threatens a strike in protest.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21--The Washington visit of Gen. Charles de Gaulle, who will arrive here tomorrow, is expected to have farreaching effects on the future relations between the United States and western Europe and may affect his own political future.

The Tokyo radio said yesterday that a photograph of Nagasaki, second Japanese city to be struck with an atomic bomb, showed that "the center of the once thriving city has been turned into a vast devastation with nothing left except rubble as far as the eyes could see."

LONDON, Aug. 21--Great Britain notified the Bulgarian Government today that she would refuse to recognize as "democratic or representative" any Government formed in elections held under present conditions in Bulgaria and under the present Bulgarian electoral law.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21--The War Production Board estimated today that 3,500,000 radios might be produced for civilian buyers by the end of the year.

District Attorney George J. Beldock of Brooklyn announced yesterday the appointment of Walter J. Higgins, a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, as the chief investigator on his staff. Mr. Higgins, an independent Democrat, who lives with his wife and family in the Bronx, was a Government agent from 1938 to 1943. He is 33 years old.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 (AP)-- The Phils won their fifth straight game tonight with a 6-3 victory over Cincinnati. It was the Phils longest winning streak of the season.

PARIS, Aug. 22--The American loan of $240,000,000 to France now under negotiation after the end of lend-lease would avoid any slump in the flow of civilian imports from the United States whose beneficial impact is now beginning to be felt, French financial authorities said tonight.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22--Short covering and a change in sentiment led to higher grain prices today on the Board of Trade. At no time was there material pressure. Commission houses were inclined to take the buying side, running the market into short covering late in the session.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22--Republican control of Congress after the 1946 election and widespread investigations of alleged waste under the Democrats were predicted by Herbert Brownell Jr., chairman of the Republican National Committee, as he turned today from a trip to the Pacific Coast.

LONDON, Aug. 23--The Government has no intention of compelling any one to invest his resources in one way rather than another, nor does it foresee any substantial change in the relations between banks and their customers, Hugh Dalton, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said today in response to a written question submitted in the House of Commons by Winston Churchill.
NORTHPORT, L.I., Aug. 23-- Alfred E. Mudge, senior partner in the law firm of Mudge, Stern, Williams Tucker, 20 Pine Street, New York, died today at his country home here. His age was 63.

Howard Davis, executive vice president of New York Tribune, Inc., and business manager of The New York Herald Tribune, will retire on Sept. 1 at his own request after twenty-seven years with that newspaper. OKINAWA, Aug. 24--American soldiers made 274 Japanese soldiers prisoners of war yesterday and today on tiny Tokashiki Island in the Kerama group, approximately seventeen miles west of Okinawa.

LONDON, Aug. 24 (U.P.)--Troops of Marshal Rodion Y. Malinovsky's Trans-Baikal Army, which has been pressing toward Peiping, have captured a town in southern Manchuria, a Soviet communique reported today.

Members of the "It's About Time Club" received heartening news yesterday when Mel Rosch, secretary of the Southern New York Fish and Game Association, announced that his organization had been stocking new bass in Westchester County waters for the past week.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24 (U.P.) --Japanese broadcasts said today that the atomic bomb dropped on Hiroshima on Aug. 6 impregnated the earth with "radioactivity" or ultra-violet rays that fatally burned 30,000 victims during the first two weeks following its explosion.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24--Gen. Charles de Gaulle replied today to President Truman's rebuke to French newspapers by saying that the press was new and inexperienced, and that while Mr. Truman had been struck by "certain articles" in French newspapers, he had been struck in the last five years by articles in the American press which had been unfavorable to France.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 24-- The Georgian brick mansion on East Island, home of the late J.P. Morgan, is to become a hotel when the present owner, Morgan Estates, Inc., gets a change of zoning to permit public hospitality instead of private entertainment.

Ten meetings in Up-State cities under auspices of the State Council of Churches will be held next month to provide counsel on marital problems for returning members of the armed forces, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 24--The abrupt termination of lend-lease has placed Britain in "a very serious financial position," Prime Minister Clement R. Attlee told the House of Commons today in a statement that former Prime Minister Winston Churchill called "very grave and disquieting news."

A brisk display of strength in the automotive issues, induced by heavy buying, furthered yesterday the bullish movement on the stock market and prices were marked up to the highest level since April, 1940.
